After Years of Uncertainty, Koreans Await Reunions North and South Koreans are preparing for reunions that in coming days will bring 100 North Koreans south, and take 100 southerners north, reassembling remnants of families separated in a war that has never officially ended since 1953.

Taiwan Leader Cancels Meeting Taiwan's new president canceled plans to meet with several members of Congress in California.
Protestants March in Ulster Thousands of Protestants paraded in Northern Ireland to mark a 300-year-old victory over Catholics, but a bomb alert shut down the main railway line into Londonderry.
Uncertainty at Lebanese Border The limited way in which Lebanon has moved its forces into the south raises new uncertainties 10 weeks after Israel ended its 22-year occupation of southern Lebanon.
Kosovo Elections Planned The United Nations administration in Kosovo announced that it would hold local elections on Oct. 28.

Bombing Raid on Iraq Iraq said that American and British planes bombed a warehouse in southern Iraq, killing two civilians. American officials acknowledged a strike near Samawa, but said the target was a command post coordinating attacks on United States and British planes that have patrolled over Iraq since the gulf war.
(NYT)
NATIONAL

Gore Preparing to Shift Focus to His Own Agenda Vice President Al Gore says that in his speech to the Democratic National Convention he will embrace President Clinton for his success in presiding over the economy but leave no doubt that ''I'm running on my own agenda, on my own voice and through my own experiences.
The Democratic Party has aggressively courted corporate supporters, who will be well represented in Los Angeles at seven-figure fund-raising events.
From his first days in Congress, Al Gore has distinguished himself by methodically researching issues and making them his own.
The Reform Party ended its convention divided in two and facing the strong likelihood of court battles.
Disease Fells California Trees Thousands of trees on the California coast are dying from a new disease, which scientists are calling sudden oak death syndrome.

Los Angeles Elite Unchanged Los Angeles will soon have a Latino majority and has a fast-growing number of Asian-Americans. But the power elite in civic organizations remains heavily white and has not changed in tandem.
Bombing Haunts Philadelphia Philadelphia has condemned replacement houses it built in a neighborhood that the police destroyed 15 years ago in a confrontation with a radical group.
NEW YORK/REGION

Two More Cases of West Nile Found on Staten Island Two more Staten Island residents, a 63-year-old woman and a 64-year-old man, have been sickened by the West Nile virus, bringing the number of human cases confirmed this year to three, New York City health officials said.

Four Shot in Brooklyn Siege After a six-hour standoff, Albert Alalouf, who had barricaded himself in his Brooklyn home with an arsenal of weapons, was killed in a gun battle that wounded three police officers.

After the Dump, Fantasies After 52 years, the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island is supposed to close in January. Public officials and residents have been embroiled in debates over what to do with the 2,200 acres left behind.
